title.narrative: 2.3 NUTRITION DEMAND

description.narrative: Individuals, households and communities have improved knowledge of essential nutrition behaviours and increased capacity to plan, manage and monitor recurrent shocks and stresses., which contributes to Early Childhood Development, Early Childhood Development (Covid), Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2020, increased proportions of girls and boys under the age of 5 years and women have equitable access to and use essential services and adopt optimal nutrition practices to reduce all forms of malnutrition, with a focus on vulnerable Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and emergency- affected communities

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Individuals, households and communities have improved knowledge of essential nutrition behaviours and increased capacity to plan,manage and monitor recurrent shocks and stresses.

description.narrative: ;UNICEF efforts to increase demand for nutrition services were evident in 2020 as the programme cumulatively reached 850,000 mothers and caregivers with at least one session of infant and young child feeding (IYCF) counselling, an increase from 618,184 reached in 2019; 186,000 children (6-23 months) were reached with multiple, micro-nutrient powders against a target of 64,000 in 2020;;1.9 million children aged 6-59 months (86% of eligible children) recieved Vitamin A Supplementation; through routine services and mass campaigns,, whilst 21% pregnant and lactating woment (PLW) received Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) tablets against a target of 50%.; | Status:Met | As-of Date:12/01/2021

title.narrative: Number of PLWs who received at least one individual counselling on IYCN(51591)
